page.title: 17Cheam Village, Surrey.
page.content: Cheam is a spring line village of Saxon origin at the northern edge of the chalk North Downs. For many centuries there were two separate clusters of houses which today are identifiable as separate shopping areas. Cheam retained its pleasant rural atmosphere until the present century when the village centre was almost totally redeveloped following large scale suburban development made possible by the opening of the railway and the provision of piped water. There are some weather_boarded, flint, timber_framed and Elizabethan brick buildings but most buildings are Victorian or twentieth century. There are two churches, a library, a modest selection of 'convenience' shops for the local population and other basic amenities. Beyond is the pleasant and historic Nonsuch Park.
